I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I  submit  for  your  approval  the  following  report  and  recommendation  on  (i)  a  proposed 
supplementary  loan;  and  (ii)  the  proposed  administration  of  a  grant  to  be  provided  by  the 
Climate Change Fund; 1 both to the Cook Islands for the Avatiu Port Development Project. 2 
 
2. 
Avatiu port, located on the island of Rarotonga, is the principal international port for the 
Cook Islands, as well as the transshipment port for cargo to the second most populated island 
of  Aitutaki  and  the  less  populated  outer  islands.  Two  loans,  one  from  the  ordinary  capital 
resources  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  other  from  the  Asian  Development 
Fund  (ADF)  were  approved  on  20  November  2008  for  the  Avatiu  Port  Development  Project. 3 
The  project  will  rehabilitate  and  expand  the  capacity  of  the  port.  The  project  comprises  (i) 
widening  the  harbor  entrance,  (ii)  dredging  to  increase  the  depth  alongside  the  wharf  plus 
dredging  and  enlarging  the  ship  turning  area,  and  (iii)  reconstructing  and  realigning  the  quay 
and repairing the adjacent wharf deck. 4  The cost of the civil works has increased as a result of 
currency realignment and an underestimation of input prices. A supplementary loan is therefore 
required to meet the increased cost of the project. 
 

II. 

THE APPROVED PROJECT 

A. 

Rationale 

3. 
The  country  is  heavily  reliant  on  international  imports  by  sea  to  support  its  tourism 
industry—the mainstay of  the  country’s  economy—as  well  as for general  imports  and  exports. 
The continued efficient operation of the port, its security against periodic cyclone events, and its 
development to accommodate changes in regional shipping methods are therefore critical to the 
Cook Islands’ economy and the social well-being of its population. 
 
The  wharf  is  weak,  aging,  and  vulnerable  to  damage  from  storms  and  impact  from 
4. 
vessels.  The  port  is  at  the  margin  of  safe  operations  for  international  cargo  vessels  currently 
serving the Cook Islands. Meanwhile, longer, deeper-draft, and more efficient cargo vessels are 
planned  for  the  Pacific  islands’  trade  in  the  next  few  years,  with  the  existing  vessels  being 
removed  from  service.  The  larger  ships  cannot  be  handled  through  Avatiu  Port  at  present, 
because of the limited depth alongside the wharf and in the harbor, berthing length limitations, 
and  an  inadequate  turning  area  within  the  harbor.  The  length  limitation  also  prevents  larger 
cruise vessels from berthing at Avatiu Port, thus limiting the economic benefit to be gained from 
this  part  of  the  tourism  market.  Without  the  project,  there  will  be  escalating  costs  for  periodic 
repair of the wharf and the port’s use will need to be restricted to smaller vessels. Costs will be 
higher, and there will be adverse economic impacts.  
 
5. 
The harbor cannot handle ships longer than about 90 meters (m), and the berth is limited 
to a 6 m draft. That effectively excludes cargo vessels above 4,000 tons and most cruise ships, 
which have to transfer passengers by the ship’s boats. The port has suffered periodic damage

 from cyclones and emergency procedures are in place to minimize losses when cyclones occur. 
The existing wharf was constructed in 1989. It is in a state of advanced deterioration because of 
deficiencies in the design and poor construction. The quay face and parts of the wharf deck are 
vulnerable to sudden failure, which could be triggered by a storm or vessel impact. Such failures 
will involve unplanned and increasingly expensive emergency repairs as the wharf continues to 
deteriorate.  Full  reconstruction  of  the  quay  is  urgently  needed,  along  with  deepening  and 
widening of the harbor to accommodate the next generation of cargo vessels and larger cruise 
ships. Once the project is completed, at least 70% of all cruise ships that currently call  will be 
able to berth at the wharf. 
 
6. 
In  2007,  the  government  adopted  a  20-year  Preventive  Infrastructure  Master  Plan  that 
was  prepared  under  a  technical  assistance  (TA) from  ADB 5 as  an  integral  part  of the  National 
Sustainable  Development  Plan  2007–2010  (NSDP). 6 The  plan  assessed  the  condition  and 
management  of  existing  infrastructure,  concluding  that  lack  of  investment  in  maintenance, 
rehabilitation,  and  upgrading  has  resulted  in  aging  systems  that  do  not  provide  appropriate 
levels  of  service  for  current  demand  and  that  this  places  sustained  economic  development  at 
risk.  Following  the  Plan,  ADB  funded  project  preparatory  TA  for  the  preparation  of  an 
infrastructure  development  project  with  detailed  feasibility  studies  for  a  number  of  priority 
infrastructure investments including Avatiu port development. 7 
 
The  development  of  Avatiu  port  was  accorded  high  priority  because  of  the  risk  of 
7. 
catastrophic  failure.  By  safeguarding  the  continued  efficient  operations  and  expansion  of  the 
port,  the  project  will  ensure  that  facilities  required  for  private  sector-led  economic  growth  are 
strengthened and risks to operational efficiency are removed. 
 
8. 
that  maintaining 
macroeconomic  stability  depends  on  removing  the  binding  constraints  to  environmentally 
sustainable  private  sector-led  economic  growth  and  improving  the  quality  of  public  sector 
governance. 8 The  strategic  focus  of  the  partnership  strategy  is  derived  from  the  NSDP  and 
addresses  these  constraints  through  improved  economic  and  social  infrastructure  and  public 
sector service delivery. This directly supports implementation of the NSDP. 
 
B. 

ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  2008–2012 

Objectives and Scope 

recognizes 

9. 
The  impact  of  the  project  will  be  continued  economic  growth  and  well-being  of  the 
population.  The  outcome  of  the  project  will  be  a  secure  and  efficient  port  infrastructure  in 
Rarotonga with constraints and safety risks removed. The project will enhance safety and bring 
ship berthing and maneuvering within the harbor more closely into line with accepted maritime 
industry practice.  
 
The  physical  outputs  of  the  project  are:  (i)  harbor  dredged  to  8  m  below  chart  datum 
10. 
(from the current depth of about 6 m), (ii) widened harbor entrance (by approximately 10 m), (iii) 
demolition  of  the  outer  and  inner  berths  and  replacement  of  them  by  a  continuous  quay  (total 
straight wharf face of 270 m), (iv) new sheet piling along the new quay wall, (v) rehabilitation of 
the wharf deck back to 20 m from the wharf face, (vi) demolition of the old slip and patrol boat

D. 

Status of Project Implementation 

14. 
 As  a  result  of  delays  in  selecting  and  appointing  a  firm  of  consultants  for  design  and 
construction  supervision,  the  project  is  currently  7  months  behind  schedule.  The  delays  were 
due to CIPA’s inexperience with ADB’s processes. However, CIPA, the executing agency, has 
established the project office and the project management team in accordance with the original 
implementation  plan.  Consultants  were  appointed  in  January  2010  and  detailed  design, 
tendering, and award of contract for the civil works were accomplished without further delay by 
December  2010. 11 No  further  procurement  actions  are  required.  The  successful  bidder  has 
provided an accelerated construction program, which will, if achieved, result in completion of the 
civil works by February 2012. The contractual completion date including the contractors’ float 12 
is  July  2012.  Completion  of  construction  was  originally  expected  by  April  2012,  and  therefore 
there  is  currently  a  reasonable  expectation  that  the  original  completion  date  will  be  met. 
Implementation progress is therefore satisfactory. 
 
The original report and recommendation of the President (the original RRP) stated that 
15. 
the  project  will  climate-proof  the  wharf  by  replacing  the  existing  structure  that  is  extremely 
vulnerable  to  wave  action  and  associated forces  with  one  that  is fully  resistant  to such forces. 
Additionally, the wharf will be designed so that it can be raised along with the container yard at 
some future date, if required by a rise in sea level. Similarly, the design of the anchorage points 
for the fendering system will allow the fenders to be set at a higher level if required. The detailed 
design of the works has incorporated these features and has identified the cost of doing so. A 
grant of $0.8 million (to be administered by ADB) was provided from the Climate Change Fund 
(CCF) to meet the additional costs. 13  
 
16. 
CIPA  has  fully  complied  with  safeguard-related  assurances.  However,  the  government 
has  not  yet  complied  with  an  assurance  that  it  will  pay  the  cost  of  the  community  services 
provided  by  CIPA.  Progress  in  this  regard  was  delayed  in  2010  because  of  political  instability 
that  significantly  hampered  government  decision  making  processes.  Elections  took  place  in 
November  2010  and  dialogue  will  be  renewed  with  the  incoming  government  during  2011.  A 
new deadline of 30 November 2011 for the satisfaction of these assurances has been approved 
by ADB on 4 February 2011 through a minor change in project scope.

 III. 

THE PROPOSED SUPPLEMENTARY FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE 

A. 

The Cost Overrun 

The physical scope of the project is unchanged from that identified in the original RRP. 
17.  
The  cost  overrun  has  resulted 
from  a  combination  of  currency  movement  and  an 
underestimation  of  the  cost  of  the  civil  works.  The  financing  plan  in  the  original  RRP  allowed 
NZ$24.2 million for civil works (at mid-2008 prices, inclusive of 27.5% contingencies). However, 
the  accepted  bid  price  is  NZ$27.2 million,  which  is  12.4%  more  than the appraisal  estimate  in 
New  Zealand  dollar  terms.  However,  in  US  dollar  terms,  the  civil  works  cost  has  increased 
27.8% from $16.2 million to $20.7 million. The cost estimates in the original RRP were based on 
an  exchange  rate  of  NZ$1.00  =  $0.67  whereas  the  revised  cost  estimate  is  based  on  the 
prevailing  rate  of  NZ$1.00  =  $0.76.  Fifty-five  percent  of  the  increase  (or  about  $2.4  million)  is 
attributable  to  exchange  rate  movements  and  45%  (or  about  $2.1  million)  is  attributable  to 
underestimation of the cost. The civil works contract attracted sufficient interest for the bidding 
process  to  be  considered  competitive.  Twenty-three  entities  requested  prequalification 
questionnaires, and 7 firms were prequalified. Four firms submitted bids, 2 of which were below 
the  engineer’s  updated estimate. The  reasons for  the  cost  underestimation  are  volatility  in  the 
cost  of  construction  materials,  the  relative  isolation  of  the  project  site,  and  volatile  market 
conditions. These considerations made cost estimation difficult, with the contingency allowance 
proving insufficient.  
 
B. 

Impact on the Project 

The  project  comprises  a  single  civil  works  contract  that  must  be  completed  in  order  to 
18. 
achieve the development objectives. The government is committed to implementing the project 
as soon as possible. It has demonstrated its commitment by authorizing CIPA to award the civil 
works  contract  before  the  expiry  of  the  bid  validity  period,  while  recognizing  that  additional 
finance  will  be  required.  Potential  impacts  on  project  implementation  have  therefore  been 
avoided. 
 
C. 

Rationale 

19. 
The  scope  of  works  for  the  project  is  a  least-cost  solution  to  meeting  the  future 
operational  needs  of  Avatiu  port.  The  scope  cannot  be  reduced  without  significant  loss  of 
benefits.  The  existing  wharf  is  in  poor  condition  and  risks  catastrophic  failure.  The  overall 
rationale for upgrading the port therefore remains as described in the original RRP.

$0.80 million towards the cost of civil works (exclusive of taxes and duties).

finance economic infrastructure. 16 The second sub-program of the loan from ADB, for $6 million, 
is expected in 2011. The current and planned level of sovereign debt is sustainable.

IV. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

A. 

Technical 

26. 
Technical aspects of the project remain unchanged since appraisal for the original loans. 
Detailed  designs  have  been  completed  and  a  construction  contract  has  been  awarded.  The 
project remains technically feasible. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

27. 
The  project  economic  benefits  remain  as  assessed  in  Appendix  9  of  the  original  RRP. 
However,  because  of  the  increased  construction  cost,  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  is 
now estimated to be 13.9% (15.9% at the appraisal for the original loans). The net present value 
is  now  estimated  to  be  $2.12  million  ($5.49  million  at  appraisal).  In  terms  of  financial 
sustainability,  the  financial  internal  rate  of  return  is  reduced  from  6%  to  4.2%.  However,  the 
weighted average cost of capital is 0.58% because interest rates are lower than at appraisal and 
because of the grant financing element from the CCF. The project remains economically viable 
and financially sound.

Governance 

D.

28. 
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with the government and CIPA. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the project administration manual (footnote 17). 

The  project  is  category  B,  B,  and  C  for  environment,  resettlement,  and  indigenous

categorizations  are  unchanged  from  those  determined  for  the  original  loans.  An  initial 
environmental examination (including an environmental management plan) has been prepared 
for  the  project  and  is  available  as  a  supplementary  appendix  to  the  original  RRP.  The  current 
design  and

requirements for the CCF-funded activities, and the range of any additional potential impact that

E. 

Risks and Mitigating Measures 

30.  Major risks and mitigating measures are described in detail in the original RRP. Financial 
risks were identified as the management effectiveness and financial control exercised by CIPA 
over its port operating costs, as well as  in setting levels of port charges to adequately recover 
these  costs  and  to  meet  CIPA’s  debt  service  and  government  dividend  obligations.  Since 
appraisal  for  the  original  loans,  CIPA  has  increased  its  operating  revenues  (for  both  FY2009 
and  FY2010)  through  efficiency  improvements  and  a  10%  increase  in  port  charges, 
notwithstanding a downturn in shipping volumes. The downturn was due to (i) global economic 
conditions  during  FY2008  through  FY2010,  and  (ii)  the  loss  of  scheduled  visits  by  Forum 
Shipping Line. In the latter case, Pacific Direct Line resumed the Forum schedule in April 2010. 
GDP is expected to grow by 2.9% in FY2011, 9.1% in FY2012, and 7.4% in FY2013, reflecting 
growth  in  real  GDP  and  inflation.  Significant  growth  is  forecast  to  result  from  the  adoption  of 
aggressive  marketing  for  tourism,  including  the  expansion  of  air  services,  though  underlying 
growth  will  be  dependent  on  the  rate  of  growth  of  the  global  economy  (footnote  15).  Rapid 
expansion of tourism is expected to result in significantly increased demand for cargo services. 
 

V.

conform  to  all  applicable  ADB  policies  including  those  concerning  anticorruption  measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement, as described in detail 
in the project administration manual and loan documents. 
 
32. 
The government and CIPA have agreed with ADB on certain covenants for the project, 
which  are  set  forth  in  the  supplementary  loan  agreement,  the  grant  agreement,  and  the 
amended project agreement. 
 
33. 
In addition to the standard conditions for effectiveness, the following conditions apply (i)

government and CIPA and shall have become legally binding upon the government and CIPA.
